title: 110_hr5515
content: The amendment to Section 233(e) of the Act allows agreements to enter into force either according to their terms or after 60 days of transmittal to Congress. Whenever an agreement under this section is transmitted to Congress, copies must be delivered to both Houses on the same day. The document must also include a determination by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration. The Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration will determine if there will be a net reduction in the actuarial balance of the social security system over a 75-year period following the agreement, equal to at least 0.005 percent of the present value of taxable payroll. The actuarial balance is the difference between the adjusted summarized income rate and cost rate over a period. Taxable payroll includes total wages and self-employment income for that period. The adjusted summarized income rate is the percentage ratio of the sum over a period. The adjusted summarized income rate and cost rate are key factors in determining the actuarial balance over a period. The income rate is the sum of the trust fund balance and total income from taxes, while the cost rate includes the cost and targeted trust fund balance. These rates are expressed as a percentage of the taxable payroll for the period. The trust fund balance is the combined balance of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. Income from taxes refers to amounts deposited in the Trust Funds based on taxes under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. During the period, the Trust Funds received appropriations from taxes under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term 'cost' refers to disbursements from the Trust Funds, including benefit payments, special monthly payments to certain uninsured individuals, administrative expenses, and transfers to the Railroad Retirement program. The Trust Funds receive appropriations from taxes under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Expenses include benefit payments, administrative expenses, and transfers to the Railroad Retirement program. The target trust fund balance is the balance needed to support an OASDI trust fund ratio after a 75-year period. The Chief Actuary uses specific assumptions to determine necessary support for a 100 percent OASDI trust fund ratio. Agreements under this section are contingent on no new laws within 60 days. An agreement under this section will not take effect if a bill disapproving it is enacted within 60 days. The Chief Actuary's determination for an agreement may result in a net reduction in the social security system's actuarial balance over a 75-year period. If a bill disapproving an agreement is enacted within 60 days, the agreement will not take effect. The Chief Actuary's determination may lead to a net reduction in the social security system's actuarial balance over a 75-year period. The provisions of this paragraph are enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House, applicable only to disapproval and approval resolutions, superseding other rules to the extent of inconsistency. The constitutional right of either House to change the rules is recognized. During a 60-day period, it is a matter of highest privilege in each House of Congress to consider a bill providing for the disapproval or approval of an agreement. The constitutional right of either House to change rules relating to procedure is recognized. The amendment allows for the approval or disapproval of agreements under this section without the ability to amend them after transmission to Congress. Effective immediately for agreements transmitted after the specified date. The amendment allows for approval or disapproval of totalization arrangements under section 233 of the Social Security Act, without the ability to amend them after transmission to Congress. This includes agreements signed by the Commissioner of Social Security in June 2004. The amendment specifies that totalization agreements signed by the Commissioner of Social Security in June 2004, and transmitted to Congress after September 1, 2007, shall not enter into force until approved as per section 233(e) of the Social Security Act. The amendment specifies that totalization agreements must be transmitted to Congress with a supporting report meeting the requirements of section 233(e)(1) of the Social Security Act for approval. Additionally, biennial reports on the ongoing operation of totalization agreements must be submitted to Congress. "Biennial Oversight Reports on totalization agreements must be submitted to Congress." The Commissioner of Social Security must submit biennial reports to Congress evaluating the operation of totalization agreements. The report includes an estimate of the change in benefit costs under the social security system attributable to the agreement. The biennial report to Congress evaluates totalization agreements, including estimated changes in benefit costs, information on fraudulent receipt of benefits, and problems with the integrity of data used for determining eligibility. The Commissioner of Social Security shall submit reports evaluating totalization agreements, including data integrity, benefit cost estimates, and trends affecting social security systems. The Commissioner of Social Security must submit the initial report under section 233(f) of the Social Security Act by December 31, 2008. SEC. 203. SUSPENSION OF BENEFITS FOR INDIVIDUALS REMOVED FROM THE UNITED STATES. Section 202(n)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a new provision stating that no lump sum death payment will be made to an individual after being notified of their removal from the United States by the Commissioner of Social Security, Attorney General, or Secretary of Homeland Security. The amendments made by this section apply to individuals notified of their removal from the United States by the Commissioner of Social Security, Attorney General, or Secretary of Homeland Security after the twelfth month following the enactment of this Act.
